section.hand:
to my L. T
re
r 17 May 1592

page.lettertext:
fol.208r
May it please yo
r
L.
Count Maurice
, it is thoug[ht hath]
already inclosed the towne of
Steenwicke:
and beginnes [there]
uppon to make his approches. The
Councel of Est[ate]
goeth thither wardes to morrowe, w
t
purpose to contin[ue]
for the [time] of that service. But the general ass[embly]
of the states of every province doth remaine at the H[age]
albeit for some fortnight their meeting is differred. D[uring]
w
ch
time, and untill I am advertised of her
Hig
nes
[plea-]
sure, as touching that w
ch
I proposed upon the motion of [the]
states for the Enterprise of
Britaine,
I will be alwai[es]
w
t
the Councel: but to returne againe hither, when [yo
r
]
L. letter comes unto me, to negotiat w
t
the
states.
Heere is a gentleman of
Juliers,
at maketh an offer [to]
this contrey, to be readye to serve where they will [.]
appoint, w
t
2000 foote, to be raised in the land of
C[leve]
and Juliers, and to come unto them upon 6 weekes w[arning]
to be so intertened from 3 moneths to 3 monethes, up[on]
the receat of half pay, till their service be required.
The states have concluded to accept of this offer, an[d]
to reserve the imploiement of the men, till they knowe
w
at
her Ma
tie
will determine for Britaine, or till p[erhaps]
they shall have neede, through the Ennemies attemp[ts]
while their forces are at Steenwicke, to defend som[e other]
place, in some part of these Provinces. The[re have]
not passed as yet any perfect contract, betwe[en the]
states and the gentleman, by reason of certaine m[ony whiche]
the partie demaundeth to be paied before hand, [and the]
states will not graunt: howbeit we are alwaie[s in]
hope, that they will come to a good agreement. [The]
practise upon
Enchusen,
wherof I writte in a form[er is]
delaied by the Ennemie, but we knowe not yet the [reason]
In the cause of the company of the
Marchants Adven[turers]
there hath bin heere a meeting of Deputies on both s[ides who]
are well agreed upon divers pointes: but the cheife[st are]
referred by mutual consent to the ordering of th[e states]
who have taken further time. In the meane while the[re is a kinde]
of contentment given to them all and their trafficke is f[ree, as it]
was before.
May 17 1592.
